contents.context:
In accordance with an agreement implemented at the start of May, South Korea is sending its business people to China.
Samsung, is sending 2-hundred-15 of its employees to the country after the two sides established a 'fast track' travel system for businesses.
The move is expected to help restart economic exchange during the COVID-19 outbreak.
Those who test negative at the airport, will be exempted from the 14 day self-quarantine Beijing imposes on regular travelers.
According to Seoul's foreign ministry, the two countries will continue to create more opportunities for business travelers in the future.
Reporter : peterwjchoi@gmail.com
contents.headline:
South Korea and China to restart economic exchange with 'fast track' travel plan
Updated: 2020-05-10 16:36:15 KST

contents.context:
South Korea has confirmed a total of 47 COVID-19 cases linked to a man who visited clubs and bars in Itaewon, the city's popular multicultural neighborhood. This is according to the combined numbers announced by health authorities and local governments.

The 29-year-old patient who lives in Yongin, Gyeonggi-do Province was found to be infected after visiting five different clubs in Itaewon last Friday nightMore than one,five-hundred people visited those clubs.
One of the other patients from this new cluster of infections works at a bank call center. The call center has now been closed, and workers are currently working from home.
Health authorities are investigating whether there was another source of infection other than the patient from Yongin.
Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon held an emergency briefing on Saturday at 2 PM and made an administrative order banning the operation of clubs, bars, and other nightlife places in the city.

"Such facilities have to immediately suspend their businesses and will face severe punishments in case of violation."

He added that the order would remain in effect until further notice.
In the meantime, health officials continue to urge people who visited clubs in Itaewon from April 29 to May 6 to self-quarantine and contact 1339 or a nearby health center.
Choi Won-jong, Arirang News.
Reporter : peterwjchoi@gmail.com
contents.headline:
South Korea sees 47 new confirmed cases of COVID-19, linked to clubs in Itaewon
Updated: 2020-05-10 14:12:02 KST

contents.context:
South Korea confirmed 34 new COVID-19 patients on Sunday, most are linked to the individual who visited five clubs over last weekend.
The Central Disease Control Headquarters said 26 out of the newly confirmed are local, and 8 were imported.
It's the highest daily number since April 9 when the figures reached 39, and it also became the first time daily cases surged back above 30 since April 13.
The newly confirmed patients are scattered across the nation, with the majority living in the capital area.
The total number of COVID-19 cases in South Korea reached 10,8-hundred-74 with the death toll staying at 2-hundred-56.

Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea sees 34 new COVID-19 patients Sunday, highest since April 9
Updated: 2020-05-10 14:12:02 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in vowed to turn the COVID-19 crisis into an opportunity so that South Korea can take a leading role in the world.
During a special public address on Sunday to mark his third year in office, the South Korean leader stressed that although we cannot lower our guard yet,. the government will use the relatively rapid stabilization phase as a turning point for enhancing economic vitality.
To that end, he vowed to turn the country into a digital powerhouse by fostering new growth industries -- pointing out that South Korea has strengths in post-COVID-19 related sectors, such as intact medical services and online education.
The President vowed to push ahead with a Korean version of the New Deal -- as a national project to create jobs -- calling it a preemptive investment for the future.
Moon also plans to improve the country's employment safety net -- by opening an era of universal employment insurance which everyone can benefit from.
While vowing to take the lead in an international order of solidarity and cooperation that prioritizes people's lives and safety, he also expressed hopes Seoul and Pyeongyang can also move toward a single community of life and peace.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon lays out post-COVID-19 vision
Updated: 2020-05-10 14:12:02 KST

contents.context:
South Korea has confirmed 34 new cases of COVID-19 on Sunday, including 8 imported cases and 26 in local areas.
The Central Disease Control Headquarters said Sunday that the total number of COVID-19 cases in connection with Itaewon clubs is now at 54,,including 11 who caught the virus from people who visited the clubs.
Following Seoul's new administrative order, the Gyeonggi-do Province Governor, in an emergency briefing on Sunday, has also made an order banning the operation of clubs, bars and other nightlife places for two weeks.
The total number of COVID-19 cases in South Korea has surpassed more than 10,8-hundred with the death toll staying at 2-hundred-56.

Reporter : peterwjchoi@gmail.com
contents.headline:
South Korea confirms 54 new cases of COVID-19 linked to clubs in Itaewon
Updated: 2020-05-10 14:07:57 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in said that while not much progress has been made, South Korea and the U.S. are still communicating with North Korea, adding that the three sides are still willing to talk.
The President, however, noted that now, South Korea should focus on carrying out its own cooperation projects with the North, as compared to the past when Seoul prioritized bringing peace to the Korean peninsula through Pyeongyang-Washington talks.

"Cooperation proposals that Seoul has made so far, such as pushing with an inter-Korean railway connection project, resuming individual tours to the North, and reunions for separated families remain valid."

Though Pyeongyang has yet to respond to such offers, President Moon said that he will continue persuading the North.
The President also stressed the importance of inter-Korean cooperation in overcoming the COVID-19 pandemic.

If the two Koreas cooperate on quarantine efforts, it will be of great help for the citizens of both countries. So we suggested cooperation in the area be prioritized.

Pointing out concerns of a reoccurrence of the pandemic, President Moon said that cooperation with the North in dealing with infectious diseases, in general, is essential in maintaining public health for both sides since the two Koreas share the Demilitarized Zone.

Kim Mok-yeon, Arirang News.
Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
President Moon Jae-in says S. Korea will continue persuading N. Korea on inter-Korean cooperation
Updated: 2020-05-10 13:53:24 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in vowed to turn South Korea into a digital powerhouse by fostering future growth industries as the country prepares for a post-coronavirus era.
During a special public address on Sunday to mark his third year in office, Moon stressed that although we cannot lower our guard yet,. the government will use the relatively rapid stabilization phase as a turning point for enhancing economic vitality.
He also vowed to push ahead with a Korean version of the New Deal calling it a preemptive investment that's designed to establish digital infrastructure.

We have strengths in post-COVID-19-related industries such as non-face-to-face medical services, online education and transactions, epidemic prevention and the bio industry. We will create future growth engines by fostering three new growth industries system semiconductors, biohealth and future cars more vigorously.

Pointing out the economic repercussions of the COVID-19 crisis, Moon also plans to improve the country's social safety net by opening an era of universal employment insurance which everyone can benefit from.
He also laid out plans to bolster the country's health care system in preparation of a second wave of the outbreak.
Moon said the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which has been the COVID-19 control tower will be upgraded to the Disease Control and Prevention Administration to strengthen its expertise and independence, while he asked for parliamentary cooperation to establish a system for two vice ministers within the health ministry.


We will significantly enhance our public healthcare system and ability to respond to infectious diseases to build a safer country. These tasks are very urgent if we are to prepare for the second epidemic wave that experts predict will hit this fall or winter.

While vowing to take the lead in an international order of solidarity and cooperation, Moon also expressed hope that Seoul and Pyeongyang can move toward a single community of life and peace although he did not elaborate.

Moon said that for the remainder of his term, he will be devoted to overcoming the national crisis along with the people. He vowed to turn crisis into opportunity, stressing that South Korea's goal is taking the lead in the world. Kim Min-ji, Arirang News.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon vows to turn S. Korea into digital powerhouse
Updated: 2020-05-10 12:13:32 KST

contents.context:
South Korea has seen a total of 27 confirmed cases linked to a COVID-19 patient who visited clubs and bars in Seoul's popular multicultural neighborhood of Itaewon.
According to the Central Disease Control Headquarters on Saturday 9AM, the 27 confirmed patients include 21 who worked with the patient or are connected to the club in Itaewon. 2 of them were found to be family members, and another 2 were acquaintances.
By region, 13 confirmed cases were in Seoul, 7 were in Gyeonggi-do Province, 5 in Incheon, 1 in Chungcheongbuk-do Province and 1 in Busan.
The patient is a 29-year-old man who lives in Yongin, Gyeonggi-do Province who was found to be infected after having visited five different clubs in Itaewon last Friday night. More than one,five-hundred people visited those clubs.
Quarantine authorities are investigating whether there was another source of infection other than the patient from Yongin. They urged people who visited clubs in Itaewon from April 29 to May 6 to be in self-quarantine and contact 1339 or a nearby health center.
Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon held an emergency briefing on Saturday at 2 PM and imposed an administrative order to ban the operation of clubs, bars and other nightlife establishments in the city.

(KOREAN- )
"Such facilities have to immediately suspend their businesses and will face severe punishments in case of violation."

He added that the order would remain in effect until further notice.
The government will also establish a system where hospitals in Seoul, Gyeonggido-Province, and Incheon will cooperate to make sure patients can be assigned a hospital bed.
If the number of patients in those regions exceeds 100 in one day, health authorities and hospitals will heigthen their cooperation to assign and treat patients at designated hospitals.
Eum Ji-young Arirang News.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Seoul city to suspend clubs and bars after cluster infection in Itaewon
Updated: 2020-05-10 08:53:47 KST

contents.context:
The man visited five different clubs in Itaewon that Friday night, and those clubs were visited by more than one,five-hundred people.
The government is having trouble tracking down all these people because many of them are foreigners and it is concerned that there could be more cases coming from this transmission.

"We have announced the time the patient visited clubs King, Trunk, and Queen in the early hours of May 2nd. We ask those that could have been at those locations at that time to please stay home and refrain from going to work or going outside."

Health authorities also advise people who were out in Itaewon during those hours and who are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 to get tested for the virus.
The first patient in this local transmission was not wearing a mask inside clubs and the time of his visit comes when his virus transmission level was high.
The government emphasized that this transmission at entertainment facilities is a case that alerts people about what can happen if they do not stick to disease prevention measures.
The government has also put an administrative order banning nightclubs across the country from opening for business for one month starting from 8 PM Friday.
Hong Yoo, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
At least 17 COVID-19 cases related to Itaewon clubber

South Korean President Moon Jae-in will be making a special public address on Sunday, to mark his third year in office.
It will be broadcast live at 11 AM, local time, from the presidential press center.
Moon is expected to express his determination for Korea to overcome COVID-19 and set out his policy plans for his remaining two years in office.
He will also be taking questions from the press.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com

President Moon to make special public address to mark third year in office

We begin with the COVID-19 situation here in the nation.
South Korea has confirmed 18 new COVID-19 cases on Saturday.
Just one of the new 18 cases is imported.
That makes the nation's total number of confirmed cases 10-thousand 8-hundred 40.
With no additional deaths, the death toll remains at 256.
Over 95-hundred people have fully recovered and been sent home.

S. Korea confirms 18 new COVID-19 cases on Sat., total at 10,840

contents.context:
Here at Dongdaegu Train Station, central Daegu, a city official is waiting at the platform for the people arriving from Incheon International Airport.
These people are asymptomatic arrivals who did not get tested at the airport.
Instead, the city of Daegu is testing every single one of them, after being transported via KTX high-speed train in specially designated cars.

The officer will escort entrants to a triage center right across from the station, which keeps track of their travel schedules based on ticket purchase records.
At a separate booth, doctors are on standby to take swab samples.
But, with a lot of the people arriving being foreign nationals, there are more things to consider.

"We do have translation services, and the questionnaires are provided in multiple languages, but we often have to use body language."

"Once the testing is done, entrants can return home, either by taking their own private cars or by taking these special taxis prepared by the city."

The taxis run according to special operational rules, and with the drivers having to be fully kitted out in protective gear.

"We have to constantly sterilize people's baggage as well as the cars. And air conditioning is not allowed, to prevent the virus circulating. We open the windows instead."

Then, after the entrants' 2-week mandatory quarantine nears its end, a team of medical staff will conduct a home-visit for a second test using a moving triage center. But, for the medical workers, it brings about its own complications.

"It's hard when neighbors come and ask us which house we are visiting for testing, obviously we can't tell them. Also, most people want to keep things a secret so they ask us to get changed in areas that are out of site like on the stairs in apartment blocks."

With this extensive quarantine system, people arriving into the country are completely segregated from the moment they arrive to when they enter their homes.
Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang News, Daegu.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Daegu busy fighting imported COVID-19 cases amid stabilizing local transmission
Updated: 2020-05-08 17:04:33 KST
